'Twas when the Fields had shed their golden Grain.</br>And burning Suns had sear'd the russet Plain;</br>No more the Rose nor Hyacinth were seen,</br>Nor yellow Cowslip on the tufted Green:</br>But the rude Thistle rear'd its hoary Crown,</br>And the ripe Nettle shew'd an irksome Brown.</br>In mournful Plight the tarnish'd Groves appear,</br>And Nature weeps for the declining Year.</br>The Sun too quickly reach'd the western Sky,</br>And rising Vapours hid his ev'ning Eye:</br>Autumnal Threads around the Branches flew,</br>While the dry Stubble drank the falling Dew.

In this sick Season, at the close of Day,</br>On Lydia's Lap pale Colinetta lay;</br>Whose sallow Cheeks had lost their rosy Dye,</br>The Sparkles languished in her closing Eye.</br>Parch'd were those Lips whence Musick us'd to flow,</br>No more the Flute her weary Fingers know,</br>Yet thrice to raise her feeble Voice she try'd,</br>Thrice on her Tongue the fainting Numbers dy'd;</br>At last reviv'd, on Lydia's Neck she hung,</br>And like the Swan expiring thus she sung.

Farewel, ye Forests and delightful Hills,</br>Ye flow'ry Meadows and ye crystal Rills,</br>Ye friendly Groves to whom we us'd to run,</br>And beg a Shelter from the burning Sun.</br>Those blasted Shades all mournful now I see,</br>Who droop their Heads as tho' they wept for me.</br>The pensive Linnet has forgot to sing,</br>The Lark is silent till, returning Spring.</br>The Spring shall all those wonted Charms restore,</br>Which Colinetta must behold no more.

Farewel, ye Fields; my native Fields, adieu;</br>Whose fertile Lays my early Labours knew;</br>Where, when an Infant, I was wont to stray,</br>And gather King-cups at the closing Day.</br>How oft has Lydia told a mournful Tale,</br>By the clear Lake that shines in yonder Vale;</br>When she had done I sung a chearful Lay,</br>While the glad Goldfinch listen'd on the Spray:</br>Lur'd by my Song each jolly Swain drew near,</br>And rosy Virgins throng'd around to hear:</br>Farewel, ye Swains; ye rosy Nymphs, adieu:</br>Tho' I (unwilling) leave the Streams and you,</br>Still may soft Musick bless your happy Shore,</br>But, Colinetta, you must hear no more.

O Lydia, thou, (if wayward Tongues shou'd blame</br>My Life, and blot a harmless Maiden's Name)</br>Tell them if e'er I found a straggling Ewe,</br>Although the Owner's Name I hardly knew;</br>I fed it kindly with my Father's Hay,</br>And gave it shelter at the closing Day:</br>I never stole young Pigeons from their Dams,</br>Nor from their Pasture drove my Neighbours Lambs:</br>Nor set my Dog to hunt their Flocks away,</br>That mine might graze upon the vacant Lay.</br>When Phillida by dancing won the Prize,</br>Or Colin prais'd young Mariana's Eyes:</br>When Damon wedded Urs'la of the Grange,</br>My Cheek with Envy ne'er was seen to change:</br>When-e'er I saw Aminda cross the Plain,</br>Or walk the Forest with her darling Swain,</br>I never whisper'd to a Stander-by,</br>But hated Scandal and abhorr'd a Lye.</br>On Sundays I (as Sister Sue can tell)</br>Was always ready for the Sermon-bell:</br>I honour'd both the Teacher and the Day;</br>Nor us'd to giggle when he bid me pray:</br>Then sure for me there's something good in Store,</br>When Colinetta shall be seen no more.

When I am gone, I leave to Sister Sue</br>My Gown of Jersey, and my Aprons blue.</br>My studded Sheep-hook Phillida may take,</br>Likewise my Hay-fork and my Hazel Rake:</br>My hoarded Apples and my winter Pears</br>Be thine, O Lydia, to reward thy Cares.</br>These Nuts that late were pluck'd from yonder Tree,</br>And this Straw-basket, I bequeath to thee:</br>That Basket did these dying Fingers weave:</br>My boxen Flute to Corydon I leave,</br>So shall it charm the list'ning Nymphs around,</br>For none like him can make it sweetly sound.

In our Churchyard there grows a spreading Yew,</br>Whose dark green Leaves distil a baneful Dew:</br>Be those sad Branches o'er my Grave reclin'd,</br>And let these Words be graven on the Rind:</br>"Mark, gentle Reader, — Underneath this Tree,</br>There sleeps a Maid, old Simon's Daughter she;</br>Thou too, perhaps, ere many Weeks be o'er,</br>Like Colinetta, shalt be seen no more."

Here ends the Maid — for now the Seal of Death</br>Clos'd her pale Lips, and stop'd her rosy Breath.</br>Her sinking Eye-balls took their long Adieu,</br>And with a Sigh her harmless Spirit flew.</br>
